abstract_summ: While studies suggest that digital contact tracing is more effective than manual contact tracing, it has been observed that higher adoption rates of the contact tracing app may result in a better controlled epidemic.However, although many apps aim to protect individual privacy, the very nature of contact tracing must reveal some otherwise protected personal information.Contact tracing using smartphone technology is a powerful tool that may be employed to limit disease transmission during an epidemic or pandemic; yet, contact tracing apps present significant privacy concerns regarding the collection of personal data such as location.In order to overcome these drawbacks, digital contact tracing has been proposed that typically involves deploying a contact tracing application on people's mobile devices which can track their movements and close social interactions.As part of this study, we focus on various cryptographic techniques that can help in addressing the Private Set Intersection problem which lies at the heart of privacy respecting contact tracing.
title_summ: Safe contact tracing for COVID-19: A method without privacy breach using functional encryption techniques based-on spatio-temporal trajectory dataA note on blind contact tracing at scale with applications to the COVID-19 pandemicContact Tracing: Beyond the AppsCOVID-19 Contact Tracing and Privacy: Studying Opinion and PreferencesPrivacy Guidelines for Contact Tracing ApplicationsEpione: Lightweight Contact Tracing with Strong PrivacyPrivacy Risk and Preservation For COVID-19 Contact Tracing AppsContact Tracing: An Overview of Technologies and Cyber RisksACDC-Tracing:Towards Anonymous Citizen-Driven Contact TracingDecentralised, privacy-preserving Bayesian inference for mobile phone contact tracingA Note on Cryptographic Algorithms for Private Data Analysis in Contact Tracing ApplicationsInherent privacy limitations of decentralized contact tracing appsPeer-to-Peer Contact Tracing: Development of a Privacy-Preserving Smartphone App
title_abstract_phrases: While studies suggest that digital contact tracing is more effective than manual contact tracing, it has been observed that higher adoption rates of the contact tracing app may result in a better controlled epidemic.Contact tracing using smartphone technology is a powerful tool that may be employed to limit disease transmission during an epidemic or pandemic; yet, contact tracing apps present significant privacy concerns regarding the collection of personal data such as location.To best of our knowledge, this is the first generic work which provides privacy guidelines for contact tracing applications.We analyze the computation and communication complexities of these techniques under the typical client-server architecture utilized by contact tracing applications.As part of this study, we focus on various cryptographic techniques that can help in addressing the Private Set Intersection problem which lies at the heart of privacy respecting contact tracing.
